A 28-year-old female came to your clinic with a 2-month history of flitting arthralgia. Past medical history is unremarkable.

On examination she is afebrile. The right knee joint has mild swelling and tenderness. Other joints are clinically normal.

Complete blood count: Hb 124 g/L, WBC 9.2, ESR is 80 mm/h
Rheumatoid factor: negative
VDRL: positive
Urine: RBC 15-20/HPF

SLE is an autoimmune disease resulting in diffuse inflammation through out the body. It is associated with a number of autoantibodies including ANA and anti-dsDNA.

The diagnostic testing include
- ANA (95-99%)
- Anti dsDNA (60%) and anti-Sm (30%) - highly specific to SLE (only found)
- Decreased complement levels (correlates with disease activity)
